noun.description: A collection of things or quantity of material tied or wrapped up together.

verb.description: Tie or roll up (a number of things) together as though into a parcel.
examples: she quickly bundled up her clothes
he was bundled into a van

verb.description: Sleep fully clothed with another person, as a former local custom during courtship.

phrases: the last year hasn't been a bundle of fun
On the surface the play may not sound a bundle of fun.
The future may look bleak, but sitting in slow-moving queues of traffic day after day, travelling to destinations that we should have lived much closer to, is not exactly a bundle of laughs, either.
Bremner apart, it wasn't exactly a bundle of laughs for the delegates.
There is still time to see Liverpool's second Biennial which sounds like a bundle of fun.
origin: Middle English: perhaps originally from Old English byndelle a binding, reinforced by Low German and Dutch bundel (to which byndelle is related).
